channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Ask Sahaj: ‘Heartbroken’ mom doesn’t believe her adult kid is trans
item.description: Ask Sahaj: ‘Heartbroken’ mom doesn’t believe her adult kid is trans

item.title: See how Africa wants to redraw the world map
item.description: The Mercator projection, a centuries-old map style from the age of sail, still prevails in the internet age. Here’s what the African Union wants to use instead.

item.title: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.
item.description: How many guesses will Keyword take you today? Try to beat the average now.

item.title: Judge temporarily blocks Trump administration from rapidly deporting most unauthorized immigrants without due process
item.description: The ruling comes after immigrant rights groups challenged the president’s broad expansion of expedited removal for migrants in the United States illegally and marks a setback for his mass deportation agenda.

item.title: Missouri’s Republican governor calls a special session to redraw the state’s congressional districts
item.description: Gov. Mike Kehoe announced a special session next week with the aim of gaining one more GOP seat in the U.S. House of Representatives. President Donald Trump has increased pressure on states to redraw congressional districts in hopes of beefing up his party’s chances of holding onto the House in the 2026 midterms.

item.title: Trump officials fire more than half a dozen EPA employees for signing letter criticizing the agency's leadership and direction
item.description: The move to terminate at least seven staffers marks an escalation in the administration’s effort to clamp down on dissent within the federal bureaucracy. EPA leaders had placed a total of 144 employees on leave for signing the letter nearly two months ago. Agency officials confirmed the firings, but did not say how many people had been let go.

item.title: Federal appeals court strikes down Trump's tariffs, a key part of his economic policy
item.description: The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit ruled that a 1977 law, called the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, or IEEPA, could not be used to impose most of Trump’s tariffs. The law is used in the case of threats against the country.

item.title: The 10 best college football towns in the country, according to our sports and travel writers
item.description: Fall colors. Buzzing student bodies. Alumni reliving glory days. If you visit any one of these towns before kickoff, you’ll feel the magic, and maybe learn a new cheer or two.

item.title: Republican Sen. Joni Ernst will not seek reelection in Iowa, people familiar with her decision say
item.description: The decision creates an opportunity for Democrats next year in their long-odds push to regain control of the Senate. Ernst was first elected to the Senate in 2014 and comfortably won reelection in 2020. Iowa has been a staunchly Republican state in recent elections, though the GOP has faced some political headwinds there this year.

item.title: Two Northern Virginia school districts sue Education Department as agency seeks to freeze funding over gender policies
item.description: The lawsuits filed by Arlington and Fairfax County public school districts come after the Education Department said it would require five Northern Virginia districts to seek reimbursement for certain federal grants, as well as begin the process of pulling other funding, in response to local leaders rejecting a call to change policies that allow students to use facilities like bathrooms and locker rooms that match their gender identity.

item.title: Happening now: Do you need a prescription for the new coronavirus vaccines? We’re answering your questions.
item.description: The Food and Drug Administration narrowed approval of new coronavirus vaccines to those 65 and over or those with conditions that make them more susceptible to severe illness. Meanwhile, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is reeling after the White House fired its director. What questions do you have about the new vaccine policy and the state of the CDC? The Post’s health team is answering your questions during a live chat now. Send in your questions here.

item.title: In Trump’s latest test of Congress’s spending authority, White House cancels nearly $5 billion in previously approved USAID funding
item.description: The administration says it can act with or without approval from lawmakers, under a little-tested theory called a “pocket rescission.”

item.title: How a hacker uncovered the data behind Tesla’s $243 million wrongful death verdict
item.description: The carmaker long said it didn’t have an electric vehicle’s stored digital account of its fatal 2019 crash involving Autopilot. The way that data finally was discovered is believed to have played into a Florida jury’s recent landmark finding that Tesla was partially liable.

item.title: 10 questions, and don't forget the bonus wager! Finish off your week with On the Record.
item.description: Think you’ve got what it takes to earn a perfect score? Take today’s longer news quiz and complete your point total for the week.

item.title: Trump revokes Kamala Harris’s Secret Service detail, which had been extended by Biden
item.description: The president’s decision comes as his 2024 Democratic opponent prepares to travel nationwide for a book tour. Federal law gives vice presidents six months of Secret Service protection after they leave office, though President Joe Biden had lengthened her detail into 2026 before he left the White House.

item.title: CDC revolt. Minneapolis victims. Newsom vs. Trump. Tesla. Ultra-processed foods. Weekend forecast. Holiday ranking. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: The U.S. has an ‘impostor nurse’ problem, and it’s grown since the pandemic
item.description: Authorities in numerous states have reported people falsely claiming to be licensed nurses or working in positions that require a nursing license without valid credentials. Staffing shortages, underfunding and a lack of oversight have exacerbated the problem, one expert said.

item.title: White House picks top RFK Jr. deputy to be acting CDC director
item.description: The selection of Jim O'Neill reflects Robert F. Kennedy Jr.'s influence as he seeks to remake federal vaccine policy. It comes a day after the White House fired Susan Monarez, the Senate-confirmed director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which prompted a series of resignations of other top CDC officials.

item.title: Cold-case killer gets 22 years in prison for 2001 murder of his ex-girlfriend’s mother in Chevy Chase, Maryland
item.description: Eugene Gligor admitted he murdered Leslie Preer but claimed he doesn’t remember how it happened. And another element remains unknown to authorities: his motive.

item.title: Turmoil at CDC as three agency leaders condemn RFK Jr., resign over director’s ouster; GOP senator urges vaccine meeting delay
item.description: As the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reeled from the ousting of its director, three senior leaders who resigned in protest told The Washington Post they were asked to participate in an unscientific vaccine recommendation process that they believe could harm the health of Americans.

item.title: Federal judge blocks Kari Lake from firing the director of Voice of America
item.description: Judge Royce Lamberth ruled that only a majority vote from the Senate-confirmed board of the broadcaster can fire its director, Michael Abramowitz, dealing a blow to the Trump administration’s effort to dismantle the service.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Conversational calisthenics with mother-in-law who is never direct
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Conversational calisthenics with mother-in-law who is never direct

item.title: Fed governor Lisa Cook sues Trump to block effort to remove her, in a case that could decide central bank independence
item.description: The Trump administration has accused Cook of making false statements on mortgage applications. Cook has yet to respond substantively to the allegations, which have yet to be proved.

item.title: ‘Sticking our necks out’ for these birds in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Thursday points.

item.title: Jim Irsay, owner of NFL’s Colts, suffered multiple overdoses before he died in May, as a doctor provided opioids and ketamine
item.description: Irsay spent the last two years of his life in the throes of a relapse that he and Indianapolis Colts executives repeatedly hid from the public, a Washington Post investigation found. This relapse, and his death, came as he was under the care of a “luxury” recovery doctor prescribing Irsay opioids and ketamine.

item.title: Minneapolis shooting. Fired CDC director. Loyalty purge. ICE plans. Meta AI. College football. Life’s origins. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Russian strikes pummel Kyiv, killing at least 12 and damaging E.U. building in fiercest attack since Trump-Putin summit
item.description: The Russian weaponry included drones and ballistic and cruise missiles and were the fiercest attack on Ukraine’s capital since President Donald Trump and President Vladimir Putin’s summit in Alaska failed to produce a ceasefire. Trump has threatened “economic war” on Russia if it doesn’t move toward a negotiated end to the conflict.

item.title: CDC director refuses to resign, as her lawyers accuse RFK Jr. of ‘putting millions of American lives at risk’
item.description: Hours after the Department of Health and Human Services said Susan Monarez is no longer the CDC director, her lawyers said she did not resign and had not been fired. In a fiery statement, the lawyers accused HHS Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and his department of “weaponizing public health for political gain.” Tumult at the public health agency grew as three senior leaders announced their resignations.

item.title: Trump administration wants to use military base near Chicago as launchpad for potential ICE operations, officials say
item.description: Officials at Naval Station Great Lakes acknowledged having received a request from the Department of Homeland Security that seeks “limited support” for Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The discussion comes as the White House contemplates deploying thousands of U.S. troops to Chicago.

item.title: Trump, Gabbard revoked security clearance of top CIA Russia expert days after Alaska summit with Putin
item.description: The CIA officer was due to take up a prestigious assignment in Europe approved by CIA Director John Ratcliffe. Instead, she was accused of betraying her oath to the Constitution and abusing public trust in a broad, public purge of 37 current and former officials.

item.title: CDC Director Susan Monarez is being ousted weeks after confirmation to lead health agency, multiple officials say
item.description: The federal scientist was President Donald Trump’s second choice to lead the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention after he pulled the nomination of former congressman Dave Weldon.

item.title: FBI identifies Minneapolis Catholic school shooter, says it is investigating attack as a hate crime and domestic terrorism
item.description: Two children were killed and more than a dozen people were injured when the shooter opened fire through the windows of a church while children from the adjacent Annunciation Catholic School were attending Mass to mark their first week of school.

item.title: FDA limits approval for new coronavirus vaccines to those considered high risk
item.description: Trump administration officials have criticized the previous public health approach to broadly recommend annual coronavirus vaccines. The new approach limits approvals to those ages 65 and older or those with a medical condition that elevates their risk of severe disease. It's unclear if others will be able to access shots.

item.title: Trump administration moves to bar states and nonprofits, such as Red Cross, from helping undocumented immigrants after disasters
item.description: The new Homeland Security requirements for receiving federal funds have sparked concern among organizations that provide relief in the aftermath of disasters. The rules also say that states and volunteer organizations must comply with immigration officials and enforcement operations.

item.title: Minneapolis gunman fired on students at worship service, killing 2 children, injuring 17 people before shooting self, officials say
item.description: The shooter, a man in his early 20s with three weapons, is dead from an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound, officials said.

item.title: Multiple children injured in shooting at Minneapolis Catholic school, hospital says; police say shooter is no longer a threat
item.description: Family members of students at Annunciation Catholic School rushed to the scene, which police had cordoned off with vehicles and yellow tape.

item.title: Grand jury declines to indict D.C. man arrested for throwing a sandwich at federal law enforcement
item.description: The failure by federal prosecutors to secure an indictment Tuesday is the latest example of President Donald Trump’s surge of policing on the streets of D.C. meeting resistance in the city’s federal courthouse. This month, Sean Charles Dunn, a Justice Department employee, was charged with “assaulting, resisting, or impeding certain officers and employees of the United States.” Prosecutors could try again to secure a grand jury indictment.

item.title: A draw at the Kennedy Center in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: D.C. judges and grand jurors push back on Trump policing surge
item.description: A federal magistrate judge said one arrest in D.C. was preceded by the “most illegal search I’ve seen in my life.” In another case, a grand jury refused three times to issue an indictment against a woman accused of assaulting a federal officer.

item.title: U.S. Transportation Department plans to take over D.C.’s Union Station
item.description: It’s not clear how dramatic the change will be for the transit hub, which connects regional trains and buses to the Metro system. But it is another example of the White House exerting power over the District as National Guard soldiers and federal law enforcement officers continue to patrol the city.

item.title: Death penalty. FEMA letter. Federal Reserve. School ‘swattings.’ AI test. Cracker Barrel. Taylor Swift’s ring. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump administration places several FEMA employees on leave after they signed a letter criticizing the agency’s leadership
item.description: Federal Emergency Management Agency officials informed some staffers that they were no longer on active duty after about 180 current and former employees sent a letter Monday arguing current leaders’ inexperience and approach could result in a disaster on the level of Hurricane Katrina, according to documents reviewed by The Washington Post.

item.title: Trump’s latest attempt to erode the Fed’s independence is dangerous, the Editorial Board writes
item.description: Frustration with the central bank is understandable, but trying to fire Lisa Cook is not the answer.

item.title: Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce announce their engagement on Instagram
item.description: The pop star and Kansas City Chiefs tight end have dated since 2023.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Nieces prefer getting cash gifts and not sending thank-you notes
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Nieces prefer getting cash gifts and not sending thank-you notes

item.title: Federal judge dismisses Justice Department lawsuit against all 15 of Maryland’s judges over handling of deportations
item.description: Judge Thomas T. Cullen ruled that the Maryland bench was within its rights to pause deportations for two business days in cases where a habeas corpus petition was filed.

item.title: A controversial redesign in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: The six factions of Trumpworld: The president melds a contentious coalition
item.description: President Donald Trump’s coalition is built for internal conflict — held together by fealty to him but riven by differences on immigration, tariffs, abortion and other policies.

item.title: Federal Reserve. Flag burning. Epstein files. Israeli attack. Screwworm. World map. Teacherless school. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.
